sections.heading: ABSTRACT
sections.text: The 3’ à 5’ exonuclease TREX1 functions in vivo to degrade DNA and prevent chronic immune activation through the cGAS-STING pathway. sections.heading: INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Three-prime Repair EXonuclease 1 (TREX1) is a 3’ à 5’ exonuclease1 that functions to degrade DNA and prevent aberrant DNA-sensing through the cGAS-STING pathway (reviewed in ref2), and TREX1 mutations are associated with a spectrum of autoimmune disorders (reviewed in ref3). While it’s clear that TREX1 activity in hematopoietic cells is the deciding factor in whether or not discernable pathology occurs4,5, the source(s) of TREX1’s pathogenically relevant biological substrate(s) remains an area of active investigation (ex. replication intermediates6, retroelements7, micronuclei8, enucleated erythroblast DNA9). Biochemical studies of TREX1 indicate robust exonuclease activity on single- (ss) and double-stranded (ds) DNA substrates (but not RNA or RNA-DNA duplexes)1,10–12, and suggest a preference for ss- over dsDNA10. Collectively, these findings perpetuate the hypothesis that TREX1’s pathogenically relevant in vivo substrate is ssDNA. However, the nucleic acid sensor driving pathology in TREX1 mutants13–15, cGAS, has specificity for dsDNA16. Furthermore, the TREX1 p.D18N variant is dominant for aggressive autoimmune phenotypes in vivo3,17, but the recombinant TREX1D18N mutant enzymes only recapitulate this dominance in vitro on dsDNA (not ssDNA) substrates17–19. Collectively, these in vitro and in vivo data make the contrary suggestion that dsDNA, not ssDNA, is the pathogenically relevant TREX1 substrate. Consequently, the question of TREX1’s biochemical preference for ds- versus ssDNA remains highly relevant to its biological function. Similarly, TREX1’s obligate homodimer structure10,20–22 is likely relevant to its biological function, but this relationship is not fully understood. Obligate homodimerization is not a necessity for catalytic activity in many other exonucleases23,24, and this implies a function specific to TREX1’s biological role. We have previously demonstrated that residues from one protomer communicate across TREX1’s dimer interface and contribute to activity in the opposing protomer21,25. While these studies establish that TREX1’s homodimer structure is critical for its exonuclease activity, they don’t explain what biological or evolutionary imperative this serves. One model supported by existing studies21,25 is that the presence and/or conformation of substrate in one protomer can affect activity in the opposing protomer. Potential explanations for such inter-protomer communication might include inter-protomer regulation of catalysis and/or binding, or an in vivo substrate binding mechanism that requires simultaneous engagement of the active-sites. The former explanation is supported by reports about the exonuclease activities of TREX1D18N heterodimers17,19, which suggest the D18N heterodimer doesn’t degrade dsDNA but degrades ssDNA at ~50% wild-type rate. While these collective data have provided an initial framework for understanding TREX1’s obligate homodimer structure, elucidating its deeper purpose requires more mechanistic interrogations. In this work we use a combination of biochemical and computational approaches to interrogate TREX1’s preference for single- versus double-stranded DNA and the functional purpose(s) of its obligate homodimer structure. The relative biochemical affinities of TREX1 for ss- versus dsDNA are convincingly demonstrated, and residues contributing to differential binding are proposed. As part of these endeavors, a new robust kinetic model of TREX1 exonuclease activity is also developed and validated from biochemical data. Finally, we explain prior observations about the TREX1 D18N heterodimer’s activity, and we further interrogate the phenomenon of inter-protomer communication in the TREX1 homodimer via molecular dynamics simulations.

sections.heading: RESULTS
sections.text:
Determination of TREX1’s kcat and Km: The catalytic rate (kcat) and Michaelis-Menten (Km) constants for TREX1 with ss- and dsDNA substrates have been reported once before10, and suggest comparable affinity for the two substrates (ssDNA: kcat = 22 ± 1.1 s-1, Km = 19 ± 4.0 nM; dsDNA: kcat = 11 ± 0.77 s-1, Km = 15 ± 4.4 nM). However, we re-determined TREX1’s classic kinetic constants for ss- and dsDNA substrates (Figure 1 and Table 1). For dsDNA, we developed a novel absorbance-based exonuclease assay. Briefly, recombinant human TREX11-242 enzyme (hT1) is incubated with a large, nicked plasmid substrate, then the reaction is terminated by addition of a small volume of concentrated ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), and the excised deoxynucleoside monophosphates (dNMPs) are separated via a microcentrifugal filter unit. Finally, the concentration of the dNMPs is quantified via spectroscopy and used to calculate activity rate. The sensitivity range, dNMP standard curve, and degradation linearity were all determined for the assay (Figure 1A-B), then initial velocities of hT1 reactions were quantified over a range of substrate concentrations to generate a
Michaelis-Menten curve (Figure 1C). These data indicated that kcat = 5.0 s-1 and Km = 10 nM. However, subsequent findings (see ‘Competitive Inhibition…’ section in Results) suggest only one active-site of the hT1 homodimer can degrade this ~10-kb dsDNA plasmid at a time, which implies kcat ≈ 10 s-1 based on the number of TREX1 active-sites truly available for catalysis under such conditions. Overall, our determinations of TREX1’s dsDNA kcat and Km are generally consistent with prior literature (Table 1 vs ref10). For ssDNA, we employed a reported26 gel-based assay to quantify hT1 exonuclease activities with high and low ssDNA concentrations (Figure 1D). The hT1 ssDNA kcat and Km were approximated from these activities and derived equations (Equations 7-8) using Monte-Carlo simulation. Interestingly, while the approximated kcat was in good agreement with the previous report, the approximated Km was about an order in magnitude greater (Table 1 vs ref10). Thus, our kinetic constant values for TREX1 suggest a preference for dsDNA over ssDNA, contrary to prior implications.

sections.heading: Comparison of TREX1’s ss- and dsDNA Binding Stabilities:
sections.text: To validate our kinetic assays, we investigated relative ss- and dsDNA binding stabilities for TREX1 via thermal shift assays (Figure 2), using recombinant human (hT1) and mouse (mT1) enzymes. As anticipated, hT1 gained much greater thermostability upon ds- (∆Tm ≈ +28.3 °C) versus ssDNA (∆Tm ≈ +13.6 °C) binding, and the same trend was observed for mT1 (∆Tm ≈ +20.1 vs +7.1 °C). We also note that hT1 and mT1 displayed significantly different melting temperatures as apoenzymes (Figure 2), despite their respective TREX1-DNA complexes having comparable melting temperatures. However, both apoenzymes had melting temperatures too high for direct physiological relevance to humans or mice (Tm > 50 °C).

sections.heading: Comparison of TREX1’s ss- and dsDNA Binding Dynamics:
sections.text: Our biochemical experiments indicate significantly different TREX1-dsDNA versus -ssDNA binding affinities, but prior crystal structures of these interactions only capture relatively static protein-polynucleotide contacts that are highly conserved across the two substrates22,28. To better define the amino acid residues that may contribute to the differential TREX1 binding to ss- versus dsDNA, we performed all-atoms molecular dynamics (MD) simulations with mT1 as apoenzyme, bound to 4-mer oligo, and bound to dsDNA. RMSD comparisons of mT1 against initial conditions shows that all simulations quickly equilibrate without indications of instability (Supplemental 1), and visualization of the conformational free energy maps for the mT1 backbone (Cα) in each of these systems reveals stark contrast in the distribution of structural states, particularly between the two mT1-DNA complexes (Supplemental 2). RMSF analysis of the Cα in each system identified three areas of differential fluctuation in the mT1 backbone which have the potential for direct interaction with substrate in the active-site (Figure 3A). Notably, TREX1’s flexible loop (aa. 164-175) seems differentially impacted by the two substrates, being significantly rigidified during dsDNA occupation of the active-site (Figure 3A – green markers). We also identified a short region (aa. 23-27) with the capacity to contact the 3’-terminal nucleotides of each substrate, which is mildly rigidified during 4-mer occupation and further rigidified by dsDNA occupation (Figure 3A – purple markers). Finally, another uncharacterized region (aa. 75-88) was identified (Figure 4 – orange markers), and its rigidity appears unchanged by 4-mer occupation of the active-sites while occupation by dsDNA leads to modest rigidification. We also subjected residues’ phi/psi angles across all simulations and systems to a clustering analysis. Pairwise statistical comparisons of each residue’s conformation (cluster) proportions were made between the systems and adjusted for false discovery rate (Figure 3B). As expected, several residues’ conformations were significantly altered upon both 4-mer and dsDNA occupation of the active-site (Figure 3B – blue markers). These included R174, L19, and aa. 191-193, which are all adjacent to the active-site with the potential for DNA interactions. Several residues’ conformations were only altered by dsDNA occupation (Figure 3B – red markers), including S48, S194, and Q209. Of these, S194 is closest to the active-site, and adjacent to the H195 residue previously identified as a residue of interest in TREX1 crystal structures18,22 and patient data3. Curiously, there were several residues whose conformations were affected exclusively during 4-mer occupation of the active-site (Figure 3B – green markers), but only K175 is in any apparent proximity to the active-site.

sections.heading: Kinetic Modeling of TREX1 Exonuclease Activity:
sections.text:
A classic kinetic model fails to account for several potential characteristics of TREX1 including: (1) degradation of a polymeric substrate where the relevant metric for substrate concentration (free 3’-hydroxyls) remains constant between most catalytic events, and (2) non-distributive catalytic activity. We developed a kinetic model for TREX1 (Figure 4A) that addresses these shortcomings, incorporates the idea of processivity as a probabilistic adjustment to the catalytic rate constant, and can be expanded to describe competition between TREX1 variants (Figure 4B). Our model assumes length-independent catalytic rates and irreversible catalysis, which is generally consistent with TREX1 biochemistry1,10,11,29. Under our model, reactions are described by systems of nonlinear differential equations (Equations 16.1-17.8), and the number of nucleotides processively excised by TREX1 following DNA binding is described by a discrete probability density function (Equation 18). We used empirical data to approximate our model’s kinetic constant values for hT1 exonuclease activity. Our model (Figure 4A) indicates that turnover rate (Equation 16.2) reduces to k2[ET] (classically30 Vmax) under saturating substrate conditions if enzyme-product complexing is negligible. Thus, the k2 (catalytic constant) parameters for both dsDNA and ssDNA have been empirically determined by our initial studies (Table 1). In addition, the previously reported31 ssDNA Kd value for TREX1 is applicable to our model with the classic30 relationship k%& = k&K' (Equation 19), but a value for TREX1’s dsDNA Kd is unavailable. Using the constraint of Equation 19, our ssDNA exonuclease activity rates (Figure 1D, [S] = 15 nM), and numerical solutions of Equations 16.1-5, we approximated the k1 (on-rate constant) and k-1 (off-rate constant) values that best explained our observed activity rates for a range of Ψ (processivity constant) values (Supplemental 3). Then, we compared our empirical ssDNA degradation patterns (Figure 1D, [S] = 15 nM) to those predicted by the model solutions for each processivity constant value (Figure 5A), and we found Ψ ≈ 0.75, k-1 ≈ 2.2 s-1, and k1 ≈ 5.2x107 M-1s-1 best recapitulated our data (Table 2). Since TREX1’s dsDNA Kd is unavailable, we used a reported26 fluorescence-based assay to perform competition experiments with hT1 and recombinant human TREX11-242D18N/D18N (hT1-DN) enzymes, then determined the on- and off-rate constant values that best matched our observations for a range of processivity constant values (Supplemental 4). hT1-DN can competitively inhibit wild-type enzyme on ds- but not ssDNA, despite having specifically abolished catalysis, implying this behavior is a manifestation of differing ss- versus dsDNA kinetic constant values19,25,26,31,32. To capture this hT1-DN biochemistry in our modeling, the hT1-DN kcat was set to zero and all other kinetic constants were constrained to wild-type values. We found that most processivity constant values had solutions for k1 and k-1 that could recapitulate our data, but for Ψ ≥ 0.90 there were no solutions that well recapitulated our data (Supplemental 4D-F). Under the additional assumption that Ψds ≥ Ψss, consistent with TREX1’s greater dsDNA binding stability demonstrated earlier, we infer for the TREX1-dsDNA interaction that 0.75 ≤ Ψ ≤ 0.90, 0.020 ≤ k-1 ≤ 0.10 s-1, and k1 ≈ 109 M-1s-1 (Table 2). However, kinetic constant solutions for Ψds = 0 were similar (k1 = 5.0x109 M-1s-1, k-1 = 0.30 s-1), reinforcing that drastically different TREX1 kinetic constant values for ss- versus dsDNA are necessary to explain empirical data. Strikingly, our inferred TREX1 rate constants (Table 2) indicate dsDNA Kd ≈ 20-100 pM, versus ssDNA Kd ≈ 42 nM, consistent with our earlier empirical data (Figures 1-2). Finally, we used our inferred TREX1 rate constants (Table 2) to predict (via Equation 18) the number of nucleotides TREX1 is likely to processively excise on ss- versus dsDNA substrates (Figure 5B). Interestingly, our model predicts that TREX1 is unlikely to excise more than ~10 nucleotides processively from either substrate. Notably, while TREX1 processively excising ≥7 nucleotides seems more likely for ds- than ssDNA substrates, the absolute probability of such events is still low. Competitive Inhibition Between Wild-Type and D18N TREX1 Protomers: Early biochemical investigations into the exonuclease activities of TREX1D18N variants17,19,26,32 were consistent with a model where substrate binding by one protomer caused communication across the dimer interface to prevent catalysis in the opposing protomer. However, the dsDNA activity for the heterodimers was only tested under specific substrate conditions: sub-enzyme concentrations of a bulky, nicked plasmid. Thus, the D18N heterodimer inactivity could be alternatively attributed to substrate-mediated steric hindrance of additional binding in the second protomer’s active-site, or to a sufficiently low dsDNA Kd allowing saturated substrate binding by the mutant protomers. We directly interrogated these alternative hypotheses by quantifying the hT1, hT1-DN, and recombinant human TREX11-242+/D18N (hT1-DNhet) enzymes’ exonuclease activities at sub-enzyme concentrations of the original plasmid substrate (Figure 6A) and at saturating
concentrations of a 30-bp dsDNA (Figure 6B). We observed significantly greater exonuclease activities for hT1-DNhet and a 1:1 hT1:hT1-DN mix on the oligo versus plasmid dsDNA (Figure 6C), consistent with the original data being (at least partially) attributable to substrate-mediated steric hinderance of dual active-site occupation and/or saturated binding of substrate. However, it is curious to note that the heterodimer was ~2- fold less active on the oligo dsDNA than the 1:1 hT1:hT1-DN mix, despite these reactions having the same total concentrations of wild-type and D18N protomers. Thus, our results are reconcilable with some degree of catalytic and/or substrate binding suppression via communication across TREX1’s dimer interface.

sections.heading: Inter-Protomer Dynamics of the TREX1 Homodimer:
sections.text: To interrogate the possibility dsDNA binding-mediated regulation across TREX1’s dimer interface, we performed all-atoms MD simulations with mT1 apoenzyme and mT1 bound to dsDNA in a single active-site (‘Protomer-A’) to compare dynamics of the unbound protomer (‘Protomer-B’) between systems. RMSD comparisons of mT1 against initial conditions shows that all simulations quickly equilibrate without indications of catastrophic instability (Supplemental 1), and visualization of the conformational free energy maps for the mT1 backbone (Cα) in each of these systems reveals stark contrast in the distribution of structural states in each system’s unbound protomer (Supplemental 5). An RMSF analysis revealed three distinct regions of the mT1 backbone that were rigidified by dsDNA occupation of the opposing protomer’s active-site (Figure 7A). These include TREX1’s flexible loop (aa. 164-175), whose corresponding region in the related TREX2 exonuclease has been previously implicated in DNA-binding33, and two previously unstudied regions surrounding the active-site (aa. 23-27 & 75-88). Curiously, these are the same regions impacted by DNA occupation in the resident protomer (Figure 3A). A phi/psi angle clustering analysis to identify conformationally altered residues echoed these findings, with most identified residues being located on TREX1’s flexible loop (Figure 7B). As a more general interrogation of coordinated activity between TREX1 protomers, Cα correlation analyses were performed for mT1 and an mT1:4-mer complex (Figure 8). We found positively correlated dynamics between the protomers’ α5 helices (Figure 8 – correlation 1) and between their β3 strands (Figure 8 – correlation 3), which prior reports suggest are key contributors to TREX1’s dimeric stability18,21,22, and these correlations were independent of 4-mer presence in the active-sites. Interestingly, we also found inter-protomer dynamics correlations that were dependent on the presence of 4-mer in the active-sites. These included positively correlated dynamics between TREX1’s flexible loop and α6 helix (Figure 8 – correlation 2) and between the flexible loop and aa. 79-93 (α3-α4) (Figure 8 – correlation 4), as well as negatively correlated dynamics between aa. 79-93 (α3-α4) and TREX1’s α5 helix (Figure 8 – correlation 2) and between aa. 79-93 (α3-α4) and aa. 22-31 (β1-α1-β2) (Figure 8 – correlation 6). Prior studies suggest TREX1’s flexible loop is involved in DNA binding19,33, but the other regions implicated in the DNA-dependent correlations have no previously ascribed function(s).

sections.heading: TREX1’s Substrate Preferences:
sections.text:
Our thermal shift assays (Figure 2) and determinations of kcat and Km (Table 1) suggest that, despite similar catalytic rates for the two substrates, TREX1 has much greater affinity for dsDNA than ssDNA. The kinetic constant values derived under our robust model for TREX1 exonuclease activity (Table 2) also support this assertion, and place TREX1’s dsDNA affinity at ~1000-fold higher than for ssDNA. It’s notable that there is over an order in magnitude variation between the substrates’ predicted on-rates, and that the predicted dsDNA on-rate, which is consistent with measurements of the classic kinetic constants (Table 1 and ref10), seems to strain theoretical diffusion limits34. This behavior may be explained if TREX1 is capable of ‘scanning’ nonspecifically along the DNA backbone to identify free 3’-hydroxyls, which is a proposed capability of the highly related TREX2 enzyme33,35 and wasn’t accounted for in our kinetic model of TREX1 exonuclease activity. If so, our use of a massive, nicked dsDNA species might have exaggerated TREX1’s apparent on-rate via a predominantly 1-dimensional versus 3-dimensional search for free 3’-hydroxyls, where diffusion-limited association with the DNA backbone occurs well before 3’-hydroxyl binding and catalysis. Since we used a >300-fold shorter ssDNA species, its apparent on-rate would not be as inflated by this scanning behavior. Regardless, the dsDNA off-rate is still predicted at 20-100X lower than ssDNA, so a multiple order in
magnitude difference in affinity for ds- versus ssDNA is still expected for TREX1 when accounting for scanning-based bias. Our MD simulations (Figure 3) suggest that this discrepancy in apparent binding affinity is largely attributable to tighter interactions with TREX1’s flexible loop, as well as interactions with two uncharacterized regions of the TREX1 structure: its α1 (aa. 23-27) and α3 (aa. 75-88) helices. Implication of the flexible loop corresponds well with prior literature, which demonstrates that mutation of these residues disproportionately reduces TREX1 exonuclease activity on ds- versus ssDNA19, and that the corresponding region in TREX2 contributes to DNA-binding33. Though this function hasn’t been directly demonstrated for TREX1’s flexible loop, the TREX1D18N variant enzymes’ ability to competitively inhibit wild-type enzyme is significantly reduced upon co-mutation of the flexible loop residues19, suggesting it also serves a DNA-binding role in TREX1. It’s fair to note, however, that our MD simulation substrates differed in length, not just strand number. Consequently, a length-dependent interaction of polynucleotides with TREX1’s flexible loop could also produce these results, which would be consistent with flexible loop-mediated DNA backbone ‘scanning’ behavior for TREX1 (as proposed above). While the other two implicated TREX1 regions have not been functionally characterized in prior literature, their positions relative to TREX1’s 3’-terminal nucleotide binding pocket indicate probable relevance to exonuclease activity (Figure 3A – orange and purple areas). Thus, they are prime targets for future structure-function studies of TREX1. Overall, our interrogations of TREX1’s ss- versus dsDNA binding provide insights into the likely nature of its biological substrate, and TREX1’s role in degrading it. First, TREX1’s dramatically higher affinity for dsversus ssDNA (Tables 1-2 and Figure 2) suggest that TREX1 has evolved to degrade a dsDNA species in vivo. It is tempting to posit that TREX1’s comparable catalytic rate on, and admittedly still high affinity for, ssDNA suggests it (at least also) functions to degrade ssDNA in vivo, which may well be true. However, these observations could also be biophysical consequences of how TREX1 degrades a single strand of dsDNA species. Indeed, in existing crystal structures it is evident that the 3’-terminal nucleotide, and the three subsequent nucleotides, of ss- versus dsDNA are positioned nearly identically for catalysis in the TREX1 active-site22,28, which would explain why the two substrates display similar catalytic constants. Similarly, TREX1’s sequence-independent contacts with these four 3’-terminal nucleotides and its flexible loop’s proposed nonspecific interactions with the DNA backbone might necessarily contribute some affinity for ssDNA species. Thus, TREX1’s relative affinity for ss- versus dsDNA seems the most appropriate biochemical metric for its substrate preferences. Next, the ‘scanning’ capabilities of TREX1 suggested by our kinetic model and prior TREX2 literature implicate a large biological substrate, where the benefits of a 1-dimensional search for free 3’-hydroxyls are necessary to degrade insulting nucleic acid at sufficient rates to avoid immune stimulation. Finally, and perplexingly, the processivity predicted by our kinetic model (Figure 5B) suggests that TREX1’s biological function only requires it to resect short stretches of the identified DNA strand before dissociating. These biochemical properties of TREX1 seem reminiscent of proofreading exonucleases (ex. ref36), but a canonical proofreading function is not consistent with the pathology of TREX1 mutants (reviewed in refs2,3). Finally, it’s prudent to acknowledge that our biochemical substrates are unlikely to perfectly recapitulate TREX1’s biological substrate(s), and thus the relevant in vivo kinetics could differ. Consequently, further interrogation is warranted to validate the biological significance of these biochemical properties.

sections.heading: TREX1’s Obligate Homodimer Structure:
sections.text:
Early biochemical and structural studies of TREX1 established the interdependence of protomers in the TREX1 homodimer’s exonuclease activity21,25, and later studies with the TREX1D18N dimeric variants17,19 spawned the hypothesis that DNA binding in one TREX1 protomer leads to catalytic suppression of the opposing protomer. We recapitulated these initial D18N experiments and expanded them to alternative substrate conditions (Figure 6), and our results are inconsistent with total catalytic suppression of the opposing protomer upon DNA binding. However, they are suggestive of some degree of inter-protomer negative regulation of catalysis and/or binding. Our MD analyses interrogating the effects of dsDNA binding on opposing protomer dynamics (Figure 7) support this conclusion as well, and mechanistically implicate the same regions impacted by DNA binding in the resident protomer (Figure 3): TREX1’s flexible loop (aa. 164-175), α1 helix (aa. 23-27), and α3 helix (aa. 75-88). MD correlation analyses (Figure 8) further support this hypothesis and implicate these regions, suggesting that TREX1’s flexible loop communicates across the dimer interface with α3-α4 (aa. 79-93) and with α6, and that α3-α4 (aa. 79-93) communicates across the dimer interface with β1α1-β2 (aa. 22-31). Collectively, these data are consistent with TREX1 possessing flexible loop-dependent negative cooperativity across its dimer interface. This is supported by analogous studies in TREX2 that
suggest its flexible loop is involved in binding cooperativity33,35, and by the α6 and α3-α4 regions’ direct contact with the 3’-terminal nucleotide in existing crystal structures22,28. It seems reasonable in TREX1’s case that, sequentially, the α6 and/or α3-α4 regions are the ‘sensors’ of 3’-terminal nucleotide binding and the flexible loop is the ‘effector’ of negative cooperativity, as opposed to the opposite trend. However, this cannot be definitively stated from these data alone. When paired with our substrate preference data, these findings support a model where TREX1’s homodimer structure has evolved as part of a mechanism to efficiently locate free 3’-hydroxyls on a large, nicked dsDNA substrate and degrade the nicked strand. Mechanistically, we propose that TREX1 is capable of ‘scanning’ along the dsDNA backbone of its biological substrate in search of free 3’-hydroxyls, with each flexible loop positioned on the backbone of a respective strand. Upon one protomer’s recognition of a 3’- terminal nucleotide in its binding pocket by its α6 and/or α3-α4 regions, the opposing protomer’s flexible loop is forced to release the non-scissile strand. Then, the scissile strand can be positioned for efficient catalysis in the resident protomer’s active-site. Under this model, TREX1’s ultra-fast kinetics (Tables 1-2), its flexible loop’s apparently disproportionate relevance to dsDNA exonuclease activity19, and the D18N heterodimer’s behavior (Figure 6) are quite expected. This model is, of course, inferential by nature, and warrants rigorous and highly mechanistic future studies to validate it.

sections.heading: Conclusions:
sections.text: The 3’ à 5’ exonuclease, TREX1, functions in vivo to degrade DNA and prevent chronic immune activation through the cGAS-STING pathway. TREX1 is currently described as a nonprocessive enzyme with little preference for ss- versus dsDNA, ssDNA sources are proposed as relevant TREX1 in vivo substrates, and TREX1’s obligate homodimer structure is largely unexplained. Our studies demonstrate that TREX1 is predicted to have several orders of magnitude greater affinity for ds- than ssDNA. Furthermore, we find extensively correlated dynamics between TREX1 protomers involving previously described as well as uncharacterized regions of the TREX1 enzyme, all of which have the potential to directly interact with substrate in their resident protomers. We infer that TREX1’s obligate homodimer structure is an evolutionary mechanism to efficiently scan for exposed 3’-hydroxyls and facilitate rapid catabolism of a dsDNA biological substrate. Ultimately, these studies identify potentially critical regions of the TREX1 enzyme for future functional characterization, and they provide compelling evidence that the nature of TREX1’s biological substrate should be critically reevaluated.

Wild-type protomers were expressed as a fusion protein using a pLM303x vector that encodes maltose-binding protein (MBP) linked N-terminally to TREX1. sections.text: We have published a quite detailed protocol26 for this assay, but we will summarize it here. 100 µL reactions were prepared containing a variable concentration of hT1, 20 mM TRIS (pH 7.5 @ 25°C), 5 mM MgCl2, 2 mM dithiothreitol (DTT), 15 nM or 515 nM ssDNA substrate, and 100 ng/µL bovine serum albumin (BSA). Reactions were quenched in 400 µL cold ethanol, dried in vacuo, resuspended in loading solution, then electrophoresed on a 23% urea-polyacrylamide sequencing gel and imaged on a Typhoon FLA 9500 (GE Healthcare Life Sciences). sections.heading: Quantification of Polyacrylamide Gels:
sections.text: Polyacrylamide gel images were subjected to 1D densitometry using the GelAnalyzer 2010a software. Lanes were identified automatically with software defaults, and intensity vs migration functions for each lane were subjected to background subtraction by the rolling ball method with a ‘500’ ball radius setting. Next, the peaks in each lane corresponding to various oligo sizes were manually identified using the aforementioned internal ladder as a visual reference for the expected migration positions. Then, peaks were integrated automatically to quantify relative oligo levels for all bands. These band values were subjected to quantification methods26 we have previously published to calculate the proportion of each substrate size remaining in the reaction, calculate the moles of nucleotides excised, and ultimately determine reaction rates.

sections.heading: Molecular Dynamics Simulations:
sections.text: The published structure of mTREX11-242 bound to ssDNA (PDB = ‘2IOC’) was modified in PyMOL39 to remove nucleic acid and ions. The modified structure was then used as a template for MODELLER40 to model in the flexible loops missing from the original structure. This produced the mT1 model. The original mTREX1 published structure was loaded into PyMOL39 and aligned to the mT1 model. The calcium ions and ssDNA polymers from the original structure were then superimposed on the mT1 model, and the calcium ions converted to magnesium, to generate the mT1:4-mer model. The published structure of mTREX11-242 bound to dsDNA (PDB = ‘4YNQ’) was loaded into PyMOL39 and aligned to the mT1:4-mer model. The ssDNA polymers were removed from the mT1:4-mer model, a single dsDNA from the published structure copied into the model, the published structure removed, and then the remaining molecules exported. This generated the mT1:dsDNA model. Each of the models was converted to pdb and psf files with the ‘autopsf’ functionality in VMD (v1.9.4)41, using the CHARMM ‘top_all27_prot_lipid_na.inp’ force field parameters42,43. Explicit water solvent was added to the processed models using a 10 Å padding around the existing models’ dimensions. Hydrated models were then ionized with 50 mM MgCl2 and exported. The exported pdb and psf files defined the initial conditions for the four simulation systems, constructed from the four models. Hydration and ionization were also performed in VMD (v1.9.4) using default CHARMM parameter files. Initial condition files for each system were replicated and used to initiate four MD simulations per system. MD simulations were performed with ACEMD3 (Acellera)44 on Acellera GPUs. All initial condition files were independently subjected to a 1000-step energy minimization, then simulations were initiated. Simulations were for 1000 ns each, with 4 fs steps. Structure coordinates were exported from simulations every 10 ps in xtc format. Thermostat was set to 300 K, barostat was set to 1.0132 bar, and all other parameters were left to default. Simulations ran for ~10 days each. Completed simulations were pre-processed in VMD v1.9.4. The xtc trajectory file and psf initial conditions file were loaded into the pdb initial conditions file. Simulation trajectory coordinates were loaded in 20-frame (200 ps) intervals totaling 5000 frames. After loading, simulations were unwrapped using the ‘pbc unwrap’ function. Unwrapped simulation frames were aligned to the initial conditions frame based on RMSDminimization between the protein backbones. Pre-processed simulations were exported without solvent molecules to mol2 files. The mol2 files were processed into csv files compatible with later analyses using Bash scripts.
